questions.text: A patient presents with annular lesions on the skin. Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with annular lesions? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Urticaria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Urticaria, commonly known as hives, is characterized by transient, well-circumscribed, erythematous, and edematous plaques that can be pruritic.
  • • These lesions typically appear and disappear within a few hours and do not usually form annular (ring-shaped) patterns. Urticaria can be triggered by various factors including allergens, stress, or physical stimuli, but the lesions themselves are generally not annular.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tinea corporis : This is a dermatophyte infection that commonly presents as annular, scaly plaques with a well-defined edge and central clearing. These ring-like lesions are characteristic of tinea infections.
  • • Option A. Tinea corporis
  • • Option B. Porokeratosis : This is a disorder of keratinization that presents with annular plaques with a distinct ridge-like border. The characteristic lesion of porokeratosis is an annular plaque with a raised, ridge-like border and central atrophy.
  • • Option B. Porokeratosis
  • • Option C. Pityriasis rosea : This condition often begins with a single herald patch followed by the development of multiple oval, scaly lesions that may have a ring or annular appearance. The distribution is often in a Christmas-tree pattern on the back.
  • • Option C. Pityriasis rosea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urticaria is characterized by transient erythematous plaques that do not typically present as annular lesions, unlike conditions such as tinea corporis, porokeratosis, and pityriasis rosea.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multiple anogenital warts, and the biopsy reveals squamous atypia. Among the various human papillomavirus types, which ones are classified as high-risk? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. HPV 18

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Squamous carcinoma is the most prevalent type of cancer associated with HPV infection . Among the various human papillomavirus types, HPV-16 and HPV-18 are considered high-risk and are frequently implicated in the development of cervical, vaginal, and vulval cancers. Other high-risk types include HPV-31, HPV-33, and HPV-35. Genital warts , also known as condyloma acuminata or venereal warts, are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6) and human papillomavirus 11 (HPV-11) . These types, referred to as low-risk , have a lower potential to lead to malignancy.

questions.text: Postherpetic neuralgia (PHN) is characterized by pain persisting beyond how many weeks after the onset of the rash? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Postherpetic neuralgia (PHN) is the most common and significant neurological complication of herpes zoster (shingles). It is defined as pain that persists after the herpes zoster rash has healed, typically lasting beyond 4 weeks or 1 month from the onset of the rash. This timeframe is used to differentiate PHN from the acute pain associated with the initial herpes zoster infection.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. 1 week: Pain at this stage is still considered part of the acute phase of herpes zoster, not PHN.
  • • Option A. 1 week:
  • • Option B. 2 weeks: Similar to the 1-week mark, pain persisting for 2 weeks is generally considered acute and not classified as PHN.
  • • Option B. 2 weeks:
  • • Option C. 3 weeks: Pain lasting 3 weeks may still be considered part of the acute phase, depending on the individual case, but PHN is typically defined after 4 weeks.
  • • Option C. 3 weeks:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postherpetic neuralgia is defined as pain that persists for more than 4 weeks after the onset of a herpes zoster rash

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding scleredema?

options.label: A
options.text: Scleredema is commonly associated with diabetes mellitus and affects the neck and upper back.

options.label: B
options.text: Scleredema presents with thickened, non-pitting induration of the skin without involvement of the hands and feet.

options.label: C
options.text: Scleredema is associated with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon.

options.label: D
options.text: Scleredema results in an expanded dermis due to increased mucin deposition and thick collagen fibers.

questions.correct_answer: C. Scleredema is associated with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Scleredema and scleroderma are distinct conditions, and scleredema is not associated with features like sclerodactyly, Raynaud’s phenomenon, nail fold capillary changes, or serum autoantibodies, which are characteristic of scleroderma. Scleredema primarily affects the skin on the upper back and neck, sparing the hands and feet. It involves increased mucin deposition and thickened collagen fibers without fibroblast proliferation. The most common form of scleredema is associated with diabetes mellitus, particularly in men, due to abnormal collagen synthesis and resistance to degradation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Scleredema is commonly associated with diabetes mellitus and affects the neck and upper back. This statement is true. Scleredema is frequently associated with diabetes, particularly in men, and primarily involves the neck and upper back regions, leading to skin tightening and thickening.
  • • Option
  • • A. Scleredema is commonly associated with diabetes mellitus and affects the neck and upper back.
  • • Option B. Scleredema presents with thickened, non-pitting induration of the skin without involvement of the hands and feet. This is correct. Scleredema characteristically spares the hands and feet, and it presents with non-pitting induration mainly on the back and neck.
  • • Option
  • • B. Scleredema presents with thickened, non-pitting induration of the skin without involvement of the hands and feet.
  • • Option D. Scleredema results in an expanded dermis due to increased mucin deposition and thick collagen fibers. This is also true. Scleredema is marked by thickening of the dermis caused by mucin deposition and coarse collagen fibers, which distinguish it from other skin conditions.
  • • Option
  • • D. Scleredema results in an expanded dermis due to increased mucin deposition and thick collagen fibers.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scleredema is a condition characterized by thickened, taut skin predominantly affecting the upper back and neck, often associated with diabetes. It is distinct from scleroderma, as it lacks features such as sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon. Understanding the differences between these

questions.text: A child with a history of night-blindness presented to you with the following findings. What is the diagnosis? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Phrynoderma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of a child with night blindness and multiple hyperkeratotic papules on the elbows , as depicted in the image, raises suspicion of a diagnosis called phrynoderma or toad-skin. This condition is often linked to a deficiency of vitamin A (VAD). It is characterized by the development of keratotic follicular papules , initially appearing on the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms , and subsequently spreading to the extensor surfaces of the extremities, shoulders, abdomen, back, buttocks, face, and posterior neck. While originally reported in association with vitamin A deficiency, phrynoderma is a non-specific finding that can also be observed in deficiencies of B-complex vitamins, vitamin C , vitamin E , essential fatty acids (EFA deficiency ), protein-energy malnutrition (PEM ), and general states of malnutrition.
  • • The clinical presentation of a child with night blindness and multiple hyperkeratotic papules on the elbows , as depicted in the image, raises suspicion of a diagnosis called phrynoderma or toad-skin. This condition is often linked to a deficiency of vitamin A (VAD).

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of progressive vision loss is scheduled for cataract surgery under the National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment. Which of the following is NOT an accurate guideline or inclusion criterion for cataract surgery within this national program? ( INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital

options.label: B
options.text: Perform more small incision cataract surgery

options.label: C
options.text: To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots

options.label: D
options.text: To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area.

questions.correct_answer: C. To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • To do surgery in rural area with makeshift hospital/Ots i s not advisable, suggests conducting surgeries in temporary setups or less equipped facilities, typically in rural areas. This is considered unsafe and against the guidelines because such environments cannot guarantee the sterility and safety standards required for surgical procedures.
  • • To do surgery in rural area with makeshift hospital/Ots i
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital : This refers to the standard protocol where patients identified as needing cataract surgery are instructed to come to a base or main hospital that is equipped for such procedures. This ensures that surgeries are performed in a controlled, sterile environment with appropriate medical facilities and staff.
  • • Option A. Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital
  • • Option B. Perform more small incision cataract surgery (SICS) : This statement encourages the adoption of small incision cataract surgery, which is a modern technique that allows for quicker recovery times and potentially fewer complications than traditional methods. It is particularly advantageous in resource-limited settings because it does not require expensive machinery like phacoemulsification units.
  • • Option B. Perform more small incision cataract surgery (SICS)
  • • Option D. To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area : This approach involves transporting patients from rural and remote areas to fixed, well-equipped surgical facilities, typically located in urban or suburban centers. This ensures all patients receive high-quality care in facilities that meet national and international health and safety standards.
  • • Option D. To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The primary aim of these guidelines is to ensure that all surgeries, particularly sensitive ones like cataract surgery, are performed in environments that uphold the highest standards of medical care and patient safety. The emphasis is on using modern surgical techniques and ensuring that all procedures are carried out in well-equipped, permanent medical facilities to minimize risks and enhance recovery outcomes. The standard guideline includes:
  • ➤ Village Register (Linelisting of cases) Screening camps Transport of cases to Base hospital Free surgery – fixed facility surgery approach (Reach in approach at base Hospitals preferred over Reach out approach as camp mode) Follow up of cases (for this camp mode is preferred)

Immediate treatment of tension pneumothorax is essential to prevent respiratory and cardiac arrest. The first step is to perform needle decompression, which involves inserting a large-bore needle into the affected side of the chest to release the trapped air in the triangle of safety. questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true? (NEET PF 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

options.label: B
options.text: Small blood vessels are most radioresistant

options.label: C
options.text: Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.correct_answer: A. Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This statement refers to the Inverse Square Law, which states that the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source. This means that as the distance from the radiation source increases, the intensity of the radiation decreases exponentially. This law is fundamental in radiation physics and is crucial for understanding radiation exposure and protection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Larger vessels are more radioresistant compared to smaller ones. The endothelial cells lining small vessels are more susceptible to radiation damage due to their relatively higher rate of proliferation.
  • • Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant:
  • • Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Rapidly proliferating cells are the most radiosensitive. Cells that are dividing quickly, such as those in the gastrointestinal tract, bone marrow, and reproductive tissues, are more susceptible to radiation damage because radiation primarily affects DNA during cell division.
  • • Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant:
  • • Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant: This is incorrect. The gastrointestinal (GI) tract, including the small bowel, is among the most radiosensitive organ systems in the body. This high radiosensitivity is due to the rapid turnover of the epithelial cells lining the GI tract.
  • • Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source, as described by the Inverse Square Law.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: A female presents with 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, AFI = 5 and there is no end-diastolic blood flow. What is the management? (INICET MAY 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Immediate termination

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The scenario described indicates fetal compromise, specifically with the findings of oligohydramnios (AFI = 5) and absent end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler. These are signs of severe placental insufficiency and fetal distress.
  • • Absent or Reversed End-Diastolic Flow: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound indicating severe fetal compromise. The absence of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery suggests that the fetus is not receiving adequate blood flow, leading to an increased risk of hypoxia and stillbirth. Management: Immediate Termination: For pregnancies beyond 34 weeks, immediate delivery is indicated to prevent further fetal compromise. This is because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits, given the significant risk of fetal hypoxia and potential demise.

questions.text: A woman presents with prolonged labor in emergency. She is being taken for a Cesarean section. Which of the following is the correct position in which the nurse should keep the patient on the OT table? (INICET NOV 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Supine with wedge under right hip

questions.correct_answer: A. Supine with wedge under right hip
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Supine with wedge under right hip

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The preferred position for a cesarean section is supine with a wedge under the right hip. This positioning is crucial to prevent supine hypotension syndrome, which is commonly seen in the third trimester of pregnancy.
  • • Supine hypotension syndrome:
  • • Supine hypotension syndrome:
  • • Occurs due to the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava (IVC) when the patient is in the supine position. This pressure can cause hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope. It is particularly dangerous during cesarean sections where spinal anesthesia can exacerbate hypotension. A right tilt (placing a wedge under the right hip) helps to alleviate the pressure on the IVC, thereby preventing hypotension.
  • • Occurs due to the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava (IVC) when the patient is in the supine position.
  • • This pressure can cause hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope.
  • • It is particularly dangerous during cesarean sections where spinal anesthesia can exacerbate hypotension.
  • • A right tilt (placing a wedge under the right hip) helps to alleviate the pressure on the IVC, thereby preventing hypotension.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Semi fowlers: The individual lies on the bed with the head elevated 30-45 degrees. This position is not suitable for a cesarean section.
  • • Option B. Semi fowlers:
  • • Option C. Trendelenburg with legs stirrup: This position involves having the head low and is not appropriate for a cesarean section. The reverse Trendelenburg position (head high) is also not suitable for this purpose.
  • • Option C. Trendelenburg with legs stirrup:
  • • Option D. Prone position: The prone position (lying face down) is inappropriate for cesarean sections.
  • • Option D. Prone position:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During a cesarean section, the patient should be positioned supine with a wedge under the right hip to prevent supine hypotension syndrome, which is caused by the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to hair loss and an itchy scalp that has been progressively worsening over the past few weeks. The mother reports that the boy first developed small, scaly patches on his scalp, which have since expanded and merged into a larger, hairless area with broken hair shafts. She noticed that the affected areas occasionally have a mild yellowish discharge, and the boy frequently scratches his head, which seems to worsen at night. The mother also reports swelling in his neck, which she assumes are "swollen glands." The child has no significant past medical history but has recently been playing with a neighbor’s kitten, which also seems to be losing hair. On examination, the boy has a well-demarcated, round, scaly alopecic patch on the scalp with visible broken hairs close to the scalp surface. There is mild erythema, and some pustules are visible. On palpation, there is mild tenderness, and the scalp feels boggy in the affected area. Additionally, cervical lymphadenopathy is noted on the right side. Given the clinical findings and the mother's observations, what is the most appropriate diagnostic tool to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation, including the scaly, hairless patch with broken hairs and associated cervical lymphadenopathy, strongly suggests tinea capitis, particularly the inflammatory type known as kerion, which is commonly seen in children. The KOH (potassium hydroxide) mount is the most appropriate diagnostic tool in this scenario. It involves scraping the affected area, placing the sample on a slide with KOH, and examining it under a microscope to visualize fungal spores and hyphae, which confirm the diagnosis of tinea capitis. This test distinguishes fungal infections like ectothrix (spores outside the hair shaft) and endothrix (spores inside the hair shaft) patterns that are characteristic of tinea capitis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Wood's lamp examination Wood's lamp examination can help identify some fungal infections, such as those caused by Microsporum canis, which fluoresce under UV light. However, this method is less reliable because not all tinea capitis-causing fungi fluoresce, particularly Trichophyton species, which are common in this condition.
  • • Option A. Wood's lamp examination
  • • Option C. Skin biopsy Skin biopsy is not a first-line test for diagnosing tinea capitis due to its invasive nature. It is generally reserved for atypical presentations where the diagnosis is unclear or when differentiating from other inflammatory scalp conditions.
  • • Option C. Skin biopsy
  • • Option D. Bacterial culture Bacterial culture is not appropriate in this case as it is used to identify bacterial pathogens, not fungal organisms. The symptoms and appearance strongly point towards a fungal etiology rather than a bacterial one.
  • • Option D. Bacterial culture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinea capitis, commonly seen in children, presents with scaly patches of alopecia, broken hair shafts, and sometimes boggy, inflamed areas known as kerions. The KOH mount is the preferred diagnostic method, allowing direct visualization of fungal elements. Management includes systemic antifungal medications like griseofulvin or terbinafine, with appropriate identification of the causative organism guiding therapy.

questions.text: Arrange the following in sequence? (INICET NOV 2022) Crowning Engagement Restitution External rotation
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) B, A, C, D

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The sequence of cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor is a series of positions and motions that the fetus goes through as it navigates through the birth canal. These movements are:
  • • Engagement : This is when the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet and the widest part of the head has passed through the pelvic brim. Descent : The downward movement of the fetal head within the pelvic inlet. Flexion : The fetal head bends so the chin is brought closer to the chest, presenting the smallest diameter to the birth canal. Internal Rotation : The fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis. Extension : The fetal head extends as it passes under the symphysis pubis, followed by the crowning (the fetal head remains visible at the vulva without slipping back). Crowning : The fetal head is visible at the vulva without slipping back. Restitution : The fetal head rotates to the position it was in when it engaged in the pelvis. External Rotation : The fetal shoulders rotate to align with the head. Expulsion of the rest of the body : The remainder of the fetal body is delivered.
  • • Engagement : This is when the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet and the widest part of the head has passed through the pelvic brim.
  • • Engagement
  • • Descent : The downward movement of the fetal head within the pelvic inlet.
  • • Descent
  • • Flexion : The fetal head bends so the chin is brought closer to the chest, presenting the smallest diameter to the birth canal.
  • • Flexion
  • • Internal Rotation : The fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis.
  • • Internal Rotation
  • • Extension : The fetal head extends as it passes under the symphysis pubis, followed by the crowning (the fetal head remains visible at the vulva without slipping back).
  • • Extension
  • • Crowning : The fetal head is visible at the vulva without slipping back.
  • • Crowning
  • • Restitution : The fetal head rotates to the position it was in when it engaged in the pelvis.
  • • Restitution
  • • External Rotation : The fetal shoulders rotate to align with the head.
  • • External Rotation
  • • Expulsion of the rest of the body : The remainder of the fetal body is delivered.
  • • Expulsion of the rest of the body
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. B, A, D, C : This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before restitution.
  • • Option B. B, A, D, C
  • • Option C. B, C, A, D : This sequence incorrectly places restitution before crowning.
  • • Option C. B, C, A, D
  • • Option D. B, D, A, C : This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before crowning and restitution.
  • • Option D. B, D, A, C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor occur in the following sequence: engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension (preceded by crowning), restitution, external rotation, and expulsion of the rest of the body.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 145
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 145

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen showed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Retinoblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a hallmark of retinoblastoma, indicating a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells. This specific histopathological finding is crucial for diagnosing retinoblastoma, especially in children presenting with leukocoria.
  • ➤ Different rosettes seen in retinoblastoma:
  • ➤ Different rosettes seen in retinoblastoma:
  • ➤ 1. True rosette -FLEXNER-WINTERSTEINER ROSETTE
  • ➤ This is specific for RB - hallmark of RB It consists of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that contains cytoplasmic extensions from the tumor cells, which have well-differentiated features suggestive of primitive photoreceptor cells.
  • ➤ This is specific for RB - hallmark of RB
  • ➤ It consists of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that contains cytoplasmic extensions from the tumor cells, which have well-differentiated features suggestive of primitive photoreceptor cells.
  • ➤ 2. HOMER-WRIGHT ROSETTE is a non-specific rosette seen in any of the primitive neuroectodermal tumors. Tumor cells surround a central region containing neutrophil.
  • ➤ 3. FLUERETTE is pseudo rosette because the central structure is not a part of the tumor and it consists of tumor cells around a blood vessel.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the dermatologist by her mother due to unusual lesions on her face, as shown in the image. The lesions appeared suddenly after the child applied henna during a school event. The mother reports that this has happened before with other skin products, but the child denies any pain or itching and is generally evasive about how the lesions occurred. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Dermatitis artefacta is a psychodermatological condition in which patients deliberately inflict skin lesions on themselves, often due to underlying psychological stress or disorders. This condition is common in individuals seeking attention or expressing psychological distress through physical means. The lesions are typically well-defined, unusual in shape or pattern, and located in accessible areas that the patient can easily reach, such as the face, arms, or legs. In this case, the linear pattern of lesions and the child's vague and evasive responses are classic indications of dermatitis artefacta, rather than a true allergic or infectious skin condition.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Allergic Contact Dermatitis Allergic contact dermatitis occurs due to an allergic reaction to an external substance, such as henna. Lesions are typically pruritic and present as eczematous eruptions, usually localized to the area of contact. However, the psychological pattern and non-pruritic nature seen in this case do not align with allergic contact dermatitis.
  • • Option A. Allergic Contact Dermatitis
  • • Option C. Impetigo Impetigo is a bacterial skin infection that typically presents with honey-colored crusts, often around the nose and mouth. The lesions are not self-inflicted and are usually due to bacterial colonization following minor trauma. The pattern in the image does not fit impetigo.
  • • Option C. Impetigo
  • • Option D. Erythema Multiforme Erythema multiforme is a hypersensitivity reaction often triggered by infections or drugs, presenting with target lesions, not linear or deliberately patterned plaques. It involves the palms, soles, and mucous membranes, which are not evident in this case.
  • • Option D. Erythema Multiforme

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dermatitis artefacta is a condition where patients inflict lesions on themselves, often in patterns that reflect the psychological underpinnings of the behavior. It is crucial to recognize this pattern, especially in young patients, and approach with psychological support and appropriate referrals rather than purely dermatologic treatment.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below: ( NEET PG 2019)

Educational Objective:

In the midsagittal section, the fornix is seen as an arching structure that lies inferior to the corpus callosum, the massive fiber tract connecting the two cerebral hemispheres. The body of the fornix travels anteriorly and inferiorly, eventually dividing into left and right columns which curve downward in front of the thalamus.
  • ➤ Fornix

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no other comorbid conditions develops preeclampsia. She enquires about the cause of her condition. The doctor explains that it is due to the failure of the invasion of? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.correct_answer: C. Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Preeclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery. The spiral artery supplies blood to the endometrium. In normal pregnancy, there is an invasion of the extravillous trophoblasts (specifically, endovascular trophoblasts) into the walls of the spiral arteries. This process takes place in two waves: First wave (10-12 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the decidual segments. Second wave (16-18 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments. This invasion results in the distension of the spiral arterioles, transforming them into a low-resistance, low-pressure, and high-flow system. In preeclampsia, the failure of the second wave of endovascular trophoblastic invasion into uterine vessels leads to decreased placental perfusion.
  • • Preeclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery.
  • • The spiral artery supplies blood to the endometrium. In normal pregnancy, there is an invasion of the extravillous trophoblasts (specifically, endovascular trophoblasts) into the walls of the spiral arteries.
  • • This process takes place in two waves: First wave (10-12 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the decidual segments. Second wave (16-18 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments.
  • • First wave (10-12 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the decidual segments. Second wave (16-18 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments.
  • • First wave (10-12 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the decidual segments.
  • • First wave (10-12 weeks):
  • • Second wave (16-18 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments.

  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts: Villous trophoblasts are involved in the formation of the placental villi, but they do not invade the spiral arteries.
  • • Option A. Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts:
  • • Option B. Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts: The radial arteries supply the deeper layers of the myometrium and are not primarily involved in the pathogenesis of preeclampsia.
  • • Option B. Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts:
  • • Option D. Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts: The arcuate arteries are part of the uterine arterial system, but their invasion by trophoblasts is not relevant to the development of preeclampsia.
  • • Option D. Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Preeclampsia is caused by the failure of extravillous trophoblasts to invade the spiral arteries, leading to decreased placental perfusion.

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which arch artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 6th arch

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The 6th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus on the left side.
  • ➤ Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve : The left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks under the ductus arteriosus (derived from the left 6th arch artery). In evolutionary terms, as the heart descended and the neck elongated during development, the nerve remained hooked around this artery, leading to its longer course on the left side. On the right side, the nerve hooks under the right subclavian artery (which isn't directly derived from the 6th arch but is related to its positioning). If there were a right-sided aortic arch (a rare congenital anomaly), the right recurrent laryngeal nerve would also have a longer course, similar to the left.
  • ➤ Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly matched? Oxygen: Simple Diffusion Glucose: facilitated diffusion and Na-dependent Calcium: Active transport Na: Secondary Active transport

options.label: B
options.text: If a and c are correct

options.label: C
options.text: If a, b and c are correct

options.label: D
options.text: a, b, c, & d are correct

questions.correct_answer: D. a, b, c, & d are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) a, b, c, & d are correct

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Oxygen: Simple Diffusion: Oxygen is transported by simple passive diffusion based on the concentration gradient. This process does not require any energy input and relies on the natural movement of oxygen molecules from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.
  • • Option A.
  • • Oxygen: Simple Diffusion:
  • • Option B. Glucose: facilitated diffusion and Na-dependent: Glucose is transported by facilitated diffusion using glucose transporters (GLUTs) and also through Na-dependent transport using sodium-glucose co-transporters (SGLT). GLUTs facilitate glucose transport without energy, while SGLT uses the sodium gradient to transport glucose into cells.
  • • Option B.
  • • Glucose: facilitated diffusion and Na-dependent:
  • • Option C. Calcium: Active transport: Calcium is transported by active transport mechanisms, which require energy. These mechanisms include:
  • • Option C.
  • • Calcium: Active transport:
  • • Plasma membrane Ca2+ ATPase (PMCA), which pumps calcium out of the cell. Sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX), which exchanges intracellular calcium for extracellular sodium. Additionally, calcium can be transported via receptor-mediated mechanisms, such as the IP3 receptor, facilitating calcium transport from the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) to the mitochondria.
  • • Plasma membrane Ca2+ ATPase (PMCA), which pumps calcium out of the cell.
  • • Sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX), which exchanges intracellular calcium for extracellular sodium. Additionally, calcium can be transported via receptor-mediated mechanisms, such as the IP3 receptor, facilitating calcium transport from the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) to the mitochondria.
  • • Option D. Na: Secondary Active transport: Sodium is transported using the Na+-K+ ATPase pump, which is a type of secondary active transport. This pump uses energy from ATP to move sodium out of the cell and potassium into the cell, maintaining the necessary gradients for cellular functions.
  • • Option D. Na: Secondary Active transport:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Each substance (oxygen, glucose, calcium, and sodium) has specific and correct transport mechanisms: oxygen by simple diffusion, glucose by facilitated and Na-dependent transport, calcium by active transport, and sodium by secondary active transport.
